maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves a list of printers installed on a computer.

The Get-Printer cmdlet retrieves a list of printers installed on a computer. You can also use Get-Printer to retrieve the properties of a single printer, and then use that information as input into other cmdlets.
You can use wildcard characters with Get-Printer. You can use a Get-Printer in a Windows PowerShell remoting session.
You do not need administrator credentials to run Get-Printer.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the printer about which to retrieve information.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the name of the computer from which to retrieve the printer information.
Specifies all the printer parameters to retrieve including RenderingMode and PermissionSDDL.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the name of the computer from which to retrieve the printer information.
Specifies all the printer parameters to retrieve including RenderingMode and PermissionSDDL.
Specifies the name of the printer about which to retrieve information.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet accepts no input objects.
This cmdlet outputs one or more printer objects.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- Example 1: Get a list of printers --------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command retrieves a list of printers and printer connections on the local computer.

command:example.maml:title: ---- Example 2: Get the information for a specific printer ----

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command retrieves information for one specific printer named Microsoft XPS Document Writer.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Get the detailed information for a specific printer
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-Printer -Name "Microsoft XPS Document Writer" | Format-List

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command retrieves detailed information for one specific printer named Microsoft XPS Document Writer.

command:example.maml:title: ---- Example 4: Get a list of printers on a remote computer ----

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command retrieves a list of printers from the computer named PrintServer.

command:example.maml:title: Example 5: Get a list of printer objects and then rename the printers
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Printer = Get-Printer -Name "Microsoft XPS Document Writer" PS C:\> Rename-Printer -InputObject $printer "MXDW"

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets the printer named Microsoft XPS Document Writer, and then stores it in the $Printer variable.
The second command renames the printer in $Printer by using the Rename-Printer cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes a printer from the specified computer.

The Remove-Printer cmdlet deletes a printer from the specified computer. You can specify the printer to remove by using either a printer object retrieved by Get-Printer, or by specifying a printer name.
You can use wildcard characters with Remove-Printer. You can use Remove-Printer in a Windows PowerShell remoting session.
You do not need administrator credentials to run Remove-Printer.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the printer to remove.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the name of the computer from which to remove the printer.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the name of the computer from which to remove the printer.
Specifies the name of the printer to remove.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet accepts one printer object.

dev:type.maml:name: By default, this cmdlet produces no output.

command:example.maml:title: ------------- Example 1: Remove a specific printer -------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Remove-Printer -Name "Microsoft XPS Document Writer"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the printer named Microsoft XPS Document Writer from the local computer.

command:example.maml:title: - Example 2: Remove a specific printer using a printer object -
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Printer = Get-Printer -Name "Microsoft XPS Document Writer" PS C:\> Remove-Printer -InputObject $Printer

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets the printer named Microsoft XPS Document Writer by using the Get-Printer cmdlet. The command stores the result in the $Printer variable.
The second command removes the printer in $Printer.

maml:description.maml:para: Renames the specified printer.

The Rename-Printer cmdlet renames the specified printer on a computer. You can specify the printer to rename by using either a printer object retrieved by the Get-Printer cmdlet, or by specifying a printer name.
You cannot use wildcard characters with Rename-Printer. You can use Rename-Printer in a Windows PowerShell remoting session.
You need administrator credentials to run Rename-Printer.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the printer to rename.
Specifies the new name of the printer.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the name of the printer to rename.
Specifies the new name of the printer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet accepts one printer object.

command:example.maml:title: ----------------- Example 1: Rename a printer -----------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Rename-Printer -Name "Microsoft XPS Document Writer" -NewName "MXDW"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command renames the Microsoft XPS Document Writer printer name as MXDW.

command:example.maml:title: ---- Example 2: Rename a printer by using a printer object ----
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Printer = Get-Printer -Name "Microsoft XPS Document Writer" PS C:\> Rename-Printer -InputObject $Printer -NewName "MXDW"

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets a printer named Microsoft XPS Document Writer by using Get-Printer. The command stores the result in the $Printer variable.
The second command renames the printer in $Printer as MXDW.

maml:description.maml:para: Updates the configuration of an existing printer.
The Set-Printer cmdlet updates the configuration of the specified printer.
Use the KeepPrintedJobs parameter to make a printer keep printed jobs.
You can specify the printer to update by using either a printer object retrieved by the Get-Printer cmdlet, or by specifying a printer name.
You can use wildcard characters with Set-Printer. You can use Set-Printer in a Windows PowerShell remoting session.
You need administrator credentials to run Set-Printer.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the printer to modify.

Specifies the maximum size, in megabytes, of the branch office remote offline log file for this printer. You cannot specify this parameter for unshared queues or queues that do not have branch office enabled.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the text to add to the Comment field for the specified printer.
Specifies the name of the computer on which the printer is installed.
Specifies the data type the printer uses to record print jobs.
Indicates whether branch office remote logging is disabled. You cannot specify this parameter for unshared queues.
Specifies the name of the printer driver for the printer.
Specifies whether the printer jobs in the queue are kept.
Specifies the location of the printer.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the permissions for the printer as an SDDL string.
Specifies the name of the port that is used or created for the printer.
Specifies the name of the print processor used by the printer.
Specifies the relative queue priority.
Specifies whether the printer is published in the network directory service.
Specifies the rendering mode for the printer. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- SSR
-- CSR
-- BranchOffice
Specifies the path of and name of the separator page to be used by the printer.
Specifies the name by which to share the printer on the network. To change the share state of a printer, specify the Shared parameter.
Specifies whether the printer is shared.
Specifies the starting time of printer availability.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the ending time of printer availability.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Specifies the maximum size, in megabytes, of the branch office remote offline log file for this printer. You cannot specify this parameter for unshared queues or queues that do not have branch office enabled.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the text to add to the Comment field for the specified printer.
Specifies the name of the computer on which the printer is installed.
Specifies the data type the printer uses to record print jobs.
Indicates whether branch office remote logging is disabled. You cannot specify this parameter for unshared queues.
Specifies the name of the printer driver for the printer.
Specifies whether the printer jobs in the queue are kept.
Specifies the location of the printer.
Specifies the name of the printer to modify.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the permissions for the printer as an SDDL string.
Specifies the name of the port that is used or created for the printer.
Specifies the name of the print processor used by the printer.
Specifies the relative queue priority.
Specifies whether the printer is published in the network directory service.
Specifies the rendering mode for the printer. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- SSR
-- CSR
-- BranchOffice
Specifies the path of and name of the separator page to be used by the printer.
Specifies the name by which to share the printer on the network. To change the share state of a printer, specify the Shared parameter.
Specifies whether the printer is shared.
Specifies the starting time of printer availability.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the ending time of printer availability.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet accepts one printer object.
This cmdlet returns a printer object.

command:example.maml:title: --------- Example 1: Set printer to keep printed jobs ---------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-Printer -Name "Microsoft XPS Document Writer" -KeepPrintedJobs $True

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command configures the Microsoft XPS Document Writer printer to keep printed jobs.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Set printer to keep printed jobs by using a printer object
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Printer = Get-Printer -Name "Microsoft XPS Document Writer" PS C:\> $Printer.KeepPrintedJobs = $True PS C:\> Set-Printer -InputObject $Printer

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets the printer named Microsoft XPS Document Writer by using the Get-Printer cmdlet. The command stores the result in the $Printer variable.
The second command assigns a value of $True to the KeepPrintedJobs property of the $Printer object.
The final command sets the value of revised value of $Printer.
